intro: Melasma calycinum, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia and the Pacific Islands. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, yellowish-orange flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments and has lance-shaped, hairy leaves. Its botanical features include a short, sturdy stem and small, clustered inflorescences. Melasma calycinum is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is used in traditional medicine for its purported healing properties.
